MainHeading.Title: Membership of EEC: Motion (Resumed).
MainHeading.P: The following motion was moved by the Taoiseach on Tuesday, 23rd June, 1970:
That Dáil Éireann takes note of the White Paper entitled Membership of the European Communities: Implications for Ireland.
Debate resumed on the following amendment:
To add at the end of the motion: “and urges the Government to ensure that the terms of membership to be negotiated adequately safeguard the interests of the people of Ireland.”
—(Deputy Cosgrave.)

Speaker.P: The only aspect I propose to deal with this morning is agriculture. The Government have a peculiar approach to cattle prices and milk prices. Undoubtedly, we stand to gain substantially from both these products if we join the EEC but there is a complete reluctance on the part of the Government to face up to the other major implications in respect of our agricultural policy. On the basis of current prices in the EEC, we can look forward to an increase of 60 per cent in cattle prices. Entry to the EEC will not be until 1973 at least. There will then follow a transitional period of five years. Cattle prices, therefore, become somewhat unpredictable.

The current price of a gallon of milk in the EEC is 3s 9d, whereas the average price paid to Irish farmers in 1969 was 2s 5d. One can superficially say that Irish farmers will receive an automatic increase of 1s 4d per gallon in the event of our entry into the EEC. Apart from these two increases, the Government have given no indication what other benefits our agricultural industry will obtain from entry to the EEC. There has been a complete failure on the part of the Government and on the part of those who favour rapid entry to face up to the fact that the whole agricultural pricing policy, the whole structural policy with regard to agricultural subsidies and vis-á-vis the level of food prices in the Common Market has become an unholy mess.

Although the numbers employed in agriculture in the Community have fallen dramatically the problem facing the Common Market is the high number of people still employed in agriculture. It may come as a surprise to some of the more traditionally-minded Fianna Fáil rural Deputies to learn that although only 14 per cent of the labour force is employed in agriculture that is viewed by agricultural economists in the EEC as being a matter of almost imminent catastrophe. That figure of 14 per cent is five times as many as are employed in agriculture in Britain. On entry, Ireland will have the highest proportion of its labour force of any European country employed in agriculture. The problems for us are very considerable indeed.

MainHeading.P: The deficiency payments system operated in Britain and the support subsidy levy system operated in the EEC are in many respects incompatible. The common impression in Britain and the widespread impression in the Common Market is that if negotiations break down—we shall not know that for at least a year and a half— they will break down on the price to be paid for the amendment of the common agricultural policy and, more particularly, its absorption with Britain going in. It is, therefore, superficial, inappropriate and misleading to the Irish farming community to state on a global basis that they will get 60 per cent increase on their cattle prices and an increase of 1s 4d a gallon for milk and, hey presto, all their problems will be solved. It is much more complex and traumatic for Irish farmers than a superficial approach of that nature.

The Taoiseach, in his opening speech, and Deputy Hillery in his approach to the problem have failed to deal effectively with the actual effect on Irish agriculture of the current incompatibility of the British support system for agriculture and the common agricultural policy as it now exists and has been adopted by the EEC countries. There has been very little analysis in this approach. All we had from the Minister after his visit to Luxembourg on 30th June was this particular statement in the official communiqué in which he said that the Irish Government accepted the objectives of the common agricultural policy as set out in the Treaty of Rome and fully supported the action taken by the Community to implement that policy. I must confess I view such statements with amazement on occasion. The farmers in the Republic should examine closely the implications of the support given by the Irish Government to the objectives of the common agricultural policy and all action taken by the Community.

It is true to say that in the European Commission there is a very adamant and definite view as to what should be done with agriculture in both Europe and Ireland. I am sure the Parliamentary Secretary has visions of the Italian veal producers having a long look at Irish grasslands at this point in time. I met some Italian people with agricultural interests who have not hidden their views. They would regard Ireland as a useful point from which to fly veal to Italy. Their interests in Irish dairy herds and Irish grasslands would be marginal.

The most outstanding aspect of the Commission's approach to agriculture is its adamant intention to reduce dramatically the size of the farming population in this country. I do not propose to express particular personal judgment on this. Does the Fianna Fáil Party, and do the traditional rural Deputies in that party, appreciate the implications of the general proposition to enter into the EEC? If they accept the profound structural and regional implications for agriculture, as are proposed in the Common Market by the Commission, that is fair enough. Let them be prepared to go throughout the country and explain this to the Irish farming community. Let them convey the implications of Irish entry to the EEC to the farming community. That is their democratic choice and function. If they do not appreciate the point, and if they rely on changes in the cattle and milk prices to the exclusion of all else, they are being politically dishonest.

The Commission have stated that as a result of measures which it is now introducing it is hoped that there will be an acceleration of the exodus of farmers so that by 1980 the farming population will have fallen from the current figure in the EEC of 10 million persons in agriculture to approximately 5 million persons in agriculture. If those 5 million people were to quit agriculture by 1980 in the EEC, and they occupied 12½ acres on average, then more than 60 million acres of the land in the Common Market would have to change. Part of the land will be withdrawn from agriculture and part will be kept in agriculture and used to increase the size of farms for those farmers who decide to stay in agriculture. These farms must be large enough to allow an optimum combination of production factors in order to be efficient. These larger units will have to be created by the expansion of the existing farms, by the process of amalgamation and by voluntary co-operation between farmers. Let us put that to the Fianna Fáil cumainn in rural Ireland. It may be the best thing that ever happened to Irish agriculture but then again it might not be the best thing. Let the cumainn be aware of what the implications are in terms of EEC entry.

It is important to point out to the House that there are 76,000 Irish farmers living on farms of under 30 acres. There are 52,000 Irish farmers living on farms of between 30 and 50 acres. My interpretation of the EEC policy is that, by and large, there are about 120,000 Irish farmers in this country who, on EEC criteria of agricultural viability, should not be engaged in agriculture. I put it to the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries and to the Government to say this to the Irish farmers before they start holding a referendum and before they start Christianising Europe and sending the monks, á la the Tánaiste, Deputy Childers, back to Bobbio. Let them start putting these hard facts of life before the Irish agricultural community. We would then have a more honest reaction than a very short-term one in terms of immediate changes in some agricultural prices.

I would point out to the House what has happened in respect of the Danish farms over the past couple of years. In the 1960s the number decreased by approximately 50,000. Smallholdings were amalgamated to form bigger units. In the 1970s a further reduction of approximately 70,000 in the number of farms is foreseen, leaving 80,000 farms in 1980 compared with approximately 200,000 farms in 1960. This has been a transformation. There has been a change in agriculture in Denmark too. It is not unfair to say that in this country there has been a very considerable reduction in the total number of persons employed in agriculture. Very little stress is laid on the proposition in the official estimates for Irish agriculture produced by the Irish Government in terms of future implications for Irish people and Irish farms. It is stated that if we take the Buchanan strategy, which I accept has not yet been adopted by the Irish Government, there were 330,000 people employed in agriculture four years ago. According to Buchanan, by 1986 there would be 198,000, a drop of 135,000 people in agriculture within 16 years. We must face up to the implications contained in these facts. Without making any particular judgment on the fact as such, all I wish to state to the House is that there has been an abysmal side-stepping by the Government in respect of this analysis and this urgent need to analyse the extent to which there would be massive changes in the structure of Irish agriculture on entry to the EEC.

Having said that, I shall also place on record the fact that within the EEC farm structures are perhaps somewhat worse than they are in Ireland. However, this is a cold comfort because in the EEC only 14 per cent of the population are engaged in agriculture. Within that 14 per cent there is a substantially worse situation than ours in terms of smallness of farms. Some 48 per cent of Irish holdings are between one and 30 acres. In the EEC, the figure is 67 per cent. Some 20 per cent of farms in the EEC are between 25 and 50 acres while in Ireland the figure for the same size of farms is 21.6 per cent—no great difference, although there are substantially greater numbers of small farms of up to 25 acres within the EEC than there are in Ireland. Notwithstanding that, there are far fewer persons engaged in agriculture within the Common Market than there are in Ireland. Therefore, to sum up my attitude in relation to the prospects for agriculture, I would say that for most of our products, they are reasonably good.

The White Paper estimated the volume of gross agricultural output that might be expected to show an increase by the latter years of the decade. This increase was estimated to be in the order of 30 or 40 per cent over the present level, but even with an increase of that nature in Irish agricultural output by, say, 1978, there would be a very substantial reduction in the number of persons employed in agriculture. The outlook is favourable for cattle and sheep and it is certainly favourable for lambs, but I must put a question mark where milk is concerned. In so far as pigmeat, poultry and eggs are concerned—these products account for 16 per cent of agricultural output here—the cost of production is likely to increase. This increase will arise largely from increases in cereal prices. I am not very hopeful in regard to pigmeat, poultry and eggs.

In relation to horticulture, I would like to point out, as has been borne out by the first report of the Committee on Industrial Progress, that although horticulture accounts for only 3 per cent of Irish agricultural production, there will be very severe competition for these products within the EEC.

I do not propose to deal with the Mansholt Plan because it has already been dealt with effectively by Deputy Justin Keating. However, I will say that I find in the statements of many Irish Ministers, notably the statement of the Minister for Lands—whom one might call Mansholt in reverse, or Mansholt in perverse—a total contradiction between the attitudes of the front bench members of the Government in relation to the reorganisation, the restructuring and rationalisation of agriculture and the attitude that they themselves adopt in many respects towards the rationalisation or development of Irish farms.

I shall deal briefly now with another aspect in relation to which a serious difficulty arises in respect of the Common Market and where, in so far as I am concerned, there is a rather extraordinary reversal of the normal attitude of Fianna Fáil Deputies in particular and, indeed, of Fine Gael Deputies. This is the question of the sale of land to aliens. I think that there is a glossing over of the failure to appreciate the full implications of EEC entry in this regard. I have heard opposition in various parts of the country to the purchase of land by aliens, and questions on the matter have been raised in this House by Deputies of all parties who now, apparently, support entry to the EEC. I merely want to put the facts before the House because, to my mind, support of entry to the EEC and simultaneous opposition at home to the sale of land to aliens are naturally contradictory. It is about time that the Government and those Fine Gael Deputies who support entry on a general basis should at least appreciate what exactly they are advocating. There has been action on the part of the Government in the context of Land Act legislation in so far as the sale of land to aliens is restricted substantially. However, that is generally accepted as being contradictory to the various articles of the Treaty of Rome.

I would point out to the House that acceptance of Article 52 of the treaty would mean that restrictions of the freedom of establishment of nationals of a member state will be progressively abolished in the course of the transitional period. This means that over a period of five years from 1973, assuming that that is to be the date of entry, we then abolish any internal statutory restrictions that we might have on the sale of land to non-nationals. I prefer to use the term “non-nationals” rather than aliens but I do not suffer from any perverted patriotism in that regard. Article 54 of the treaty specifically provides the enabling of a national of one state to acquire and to exploit land situated in the territory of another state.

An attempt was made in the Government's White Paper to refer quietly to this as being a qualified right under the EEC. In the White Paper of 1961-62, the Government said that this qualification was, to the extent that there was no infringement of Article 39, paragraph 2, part of the Treaty. But I would point out to the House that Article 39, paragraph 2, does no more than set out as part of the objectives of the EEC Commission the need in preparing agricultural policy within a member state to make appropriate adjustments gradually. There is nothing in article 39 to give the kind of protection that since 1962 the Government have been saying exists in relation to the sale of land to non-nationals. There is nothing in these qualifications which could be interpreted by any stretch of the imagination as being in conflict with the proposition under Article 52 permitting foreigners to buy Irish farms on the same terms as Irish nationals.

I suggest to Fianna Fáil that they go to the crossroads, to the chapel gates and to the cumainn meetings and tell the people what that involves. If their reaction is tested, it will be found that we are telling the truth in this regard. I may be wrong in thinking that this aspect of agricultural policy in the agricultural community in general. If it is understood and appreciated by the Government and the agricultural community it represents an extraordinary reversal of the views of the Fianna Fáil Party and of other spokesmen for the farming community in this country. We should also point out that land generally in the European setting is regarded as very viable, lucrative and a stable form of capital. Land values are at least three or four times that in Ireland. Land certainly has a speculative content vastly in excess of what Irish nationals would consider it to have. This is one of the considerations which have not been adverted to in relation to the Government's approach to entry into the EEC.

One of the problems facing the country and the agricultural community in particular is the lack of any dialogue on the part of the Government in regard to the implications for agriculture. It may not sound unduly snide to say that we have a Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries who, by and large, in terms of dialogue with the agricultural community, in terms of being known extensively on a personal basis to agricultural leaders, has failed to live up to the example set by his predecessors. He is certainly not as ebullient as the previous occupant of that Ministry but I do not think it can be said that Deputy Gibbons has won the confidence of Irish farmers in terms of Irish entry into the EEC. In such a situation, in a situation of political uncertainty in this country with major problems looming on the agricultural front, there is need to have the National Industrial Economic Council reconstituted as a matter of urgency. The agricultural interests in this country should be incorporated into a wider National Industrial Economic Council. I have repeatedly suggested in this House that the NIEC, with its exclusive industrial base, should have its scope broadened and its personnel extended. The Government should exercise their imagination and employ their energies to ensure that the NIEC becomes a broader National Industrial Economic Council incorporating agricultural interests.

It is no credit to the Government to say that after 13 months in power they have done nothing in this regard. One can count on one's fingers the progress made by the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries over that period. Apart from getting involved in the usual wrangles about milk prices and so on, he has not done much. While I accept that many members of the Cabinet, notably Deputy Colley and Deputy Gibbons, have a disregard for the NIEC, such a powerful organisation as the NIEC should be reconstituted. The Government never gave it the support it deserved. They should do something to integrate the agricultural community into the broader economic mainstream of activities. If they do not, I am afraid that in the context of entry into the EEC there will be yet another internal deficiency and lack of involvement.

I might also say that the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries in the context of entry into the EEC is probably in need of an injection of dynamism. I do not know what has happened to this Department over the years. It had a succession of political heads who were more involved in their own fortunes and those of the party than in developing a dynamic Department for the largest industry in this country. Apart from some exceptionally competent and tremendously capable men in the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries with a considerable knowledge of the various agricultural communities in the EEC and the effective liaison which two or three of them have with the Irish permanent staff in Brussels, there is no real contact with the agricultural community in this country. A specific section of senior personnel within the Department of Agriculture should be set up which could devote its time to examining fully the implications involved for the agricultural community in this country if we enter the EEC.

The Government produced a White Paper in relation to our entry into the EEC and the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries produced a separate paper dealing exclusively with agriculture. Over the years we have experienced this isolation of the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries. If something is not done about this you may have the Minister for External Affairs speaking in Brussels with one voice, the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries with another voice, the Department of External Affairs with still another voice and no one quite sure what to say or do in the circumstances.
Those are some of the strictures I have to make in terms of the need to reconstitute the NIEC, to reconstitute the role of the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries. This is certainly overdue.

I support the strictures of Deputy Begley in regard to the fishing industry. Deputy Begley very competently and effectively pointed out the serious difficulties facing the Irish fishing industry in the event of entry into the EEC. The Minister for External Affairs dealt with the matter in one line on 30th June in Luxembourg when he said it will be necessary to raise particular points regarding other agricultural matters, including future arrangements with regard to fisheries. That was a rather cavalier attitude to adopt in respect of this industry which will face an upleaval for the 1,600 full-time and 3,500 part-time workers in the industry.

I come now to milk prices. There is a certain intellectual dishonesty in respect to milk prices. The Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries said that, on entry into the EEC, the farmers will get 3s 9d per gallon for milk. The price currently is 2s 5d or thereabouts. In my opinion, the Minister told about one-third of the story. Admittedly, one can argue hypothetically and theoretically that the Irish farmers will have the price per gallon jumped from 2s 5d to 3s 5d. This looks very attractive, but it is far from the harsh reality of what must take place in the light of the current massive butter surplus within the EEC. It seems to be an utterly intractable problem. At the beginning of 1970 there were 350,000 tons of butter in the EEC countries. Whether it is sold to the Chinese, the Russians, or anyone else, one will certainly not get very much for it and, were it not for the increase we got in the quota to Britain, we would be in really dire straits entering the EEC. Three years ago, Mr. Harold Wilson warned British milk producers that they had very little prospect of substantial benefits within the EEC. It is rather extraordinary that he should say something utterly different from what we are being told here. In May, 1967, he said to the House of Commons:

Perhaps the House will bear with me for a moment if I say a word about milk, in respect of which the problems have been frankly analysed in the White Paper which my right hon. Friends presented to the House. As they made clear, the difficulties which it is only realistic to foresee depend on the assumption that the EEC regime for milk and milk products will be extended automatically and unamended to Britain on British entry. This must be a matter for the negotiations, but I think that it is fair to point out that the Community have found it to the advantage of their existing member-countries to encourage within the Six the expansion and output of dairy produce rather than the expansion and output of liquid milk. I should be surprised if, on reflection, those members of the Community who export dairy products will want matters so arranged on British entry as to encourage in Britain a milk policy and a system of prices for milk and milk products which would result in the production of more butter and cheese in Britain to the detriment of their own producers of milk products. It might very well suit them, and it would certainly suit us, for the present pattern of milk production in Britain to remain pretty well as it is. But we shall see.

I am not hopeful. I am full of trepidation at the prospects for Irish milk and dairy products generally within the EEC in both the short and the long term. This is one of the crucial aspects in negotiation for both Irish and British agriculture over the next 18 months. It should be pointed that we ourselves are the creators of the situation here because, at a cost of £70, £75 or £80 million, we have developed a situation in which in the short span of ten years milk intake into our creameries has doubled and the value of our exports of dairy products has quadrupled. The latter is all to the good. Our creameries handled an increase in milk of some 250 million gallons over ten years. The value of our exports in the same period rose from £8 million to an estimated £33 million this year. That is the statement of Mr. Joe McGough, general manager of Bord Bainne. Were it not for the efforts made by Bord Bainne the Irish economy, the taxpayers and the farmers would be facing an extremely critical situation.

We have doubled the output of milk over the past decade. There has been a dramatic increase in cow numbers and the yield per cow has also dramatically increased. We face a serious situation from the point of view of the disposal of milk products. I do not want to depress the House, or to deceive the House, because my relatives in mid-Cork are involved in dairy farming, but it is only fair to stress that there is a depressing prospect for butter and skim milk because of the mountain of butter which exists in the EEC countries. As Mr. McGough said, this is a matter of grave concern. I shall not emphasise it more than that. There is a massive mountain of 500,000 tons of butter which must be moved. It would appear that there is no option but to sell it at give-away prices. That is the only prospect for this massive butter surplus. It is all very well saying the Irish farmer will get an increase in the price of milk from 2s 5d to 3s 9d per gallon but, if the price of butter in England, for example, goes up from 3s or 3s 6d per pound, on EEC entry, to 5s, 6s or 8s 6d a pound, the British housewife is quite likely to shift to substitutes as have many Irish housewives who have given up buying butter because of its exceptionally high price on the home market.

Seeing that everybody, in the past couple of days, has been telling the British Government what they think, in terms of their relationship with this country, I may say that I have often felt that if half the energy expended at Press conferences, and in other aspects of related political life, were expended by Irish negotiators in seeking an increase of the Irish butter quota in Britain, the benefit to the Irish economy would be substantial. We have not been getting from Britain a very reasonable or normal deal in terms of Irish butter quotas. In relation to Common Market entry, fair enough. We must certainly maintain our present butter quota and seek to have it substantially increased on entry into the EEC.

I find it very difficult to understand the thinking behind a great many of the supposedly sympathetic British attitudes towards Irish agriculture, particularly the alleged benefits to Irish agriculture under the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Area Agreement. Britain imports some 450,000 tons of butter each year— 175,000 tons from New Zealand; 90,000 tons from Denmark; 70,000 tons from Australia, and this year, some 30,000 tons from Ireland. Let us be under no illusion. If Deputy Hillery could choke Sir Alec Douglas Home with butter——

Speaker.P: The Minister for External Affairs.

I think the Minister for External Affairs should avail of every opportunity in negotiations to point out to our British counterparts that 30,000 tons of butter out of 450,000 tons of British butter imports is not a reasonable or a fair butter quota for us to have.

My concluding comment is in respect of the regional policy of the EEC. The prospects of a regional policy have been summed up rather tersely in the Common Market monthly review of January, 1970. In an article on the Grogan Report on Regional Policy in the Community certainly one comment raised the hair on my head—what is left of it. The Minister for Lands, Deputy S. Flanagan, in particular, may be interested in this analysis of the prospects for regional policy:

MainHeading.P: The Commission offers a solution for each of the different types of regions. In the industrialised region, the existing momentum should be maintained but one should be aware of the dangers of mushrooming organisation. In the case of the semi-industrialised regions, the promotion of investment is envisaged. In the agricultural regions provisions should be made for the extension of an agrarian infrastructure.
This, then, leaves us with the regions not fit for anything.
There, the Commission expects to see built sanatoriums, rest homes, hotels and research institutes.

I am not quite sure how the Irish Government view that particular concept of a regional policy in terms of the EEC. It is as well that the people of the alleged non-prosperous and under-developed areas of this country should be aware of the possible regional effects of EEC policies on this country.

It should be a matter of major concern of the Government and, indeed, of the Minister for Lands in particular, to ensure that, in negotiations with the EEC, as far as we are concerned, there will not be any decimation of, particularly, the regions of the West of Ireland. A peculiar attitude has been taken here, a kind of writing-off, on a regional basis, of very much, in many respects, of one of the critical backbones of the country. We tend to forget that the West of Ireland has made, is making and will continue to make a very distinctive regional contribution to the Irish economy. Any attempt, therefore, by the EEC to write off the 160,000 holdings in that part of our nation should be viewed with very considerable reserve and very considerable reaction by the Government. Otherwise, I am afraid the imbalance which is already evident in the Irish community would be very profoundly accelerated and, in that case, we would be in further trouble.

These are my concluding comments on the Government's White Paper. There is a need for extensive consultation during the next 18 months on these developments as they emerge in relation to negotiations. I would make one suggestion to the Government in this regard. I am conscious that, with due regard to the Civil Service team in Brussels at the moment and to the front bench of the Government—no longer as strong as it was; certainly, there is a need to strengthen it—there is a need to ensure that the Government have the fullest consultation with the various representative interests of this country during the course of the negotiations. I would, therefore, suggest strongly to the Government that it might be an invaluable and fruitful exercise if the Irish negotiating team were enlarged to include, on a purely non-political observership information basis, representatives of the farming community, agricultural economists, senior representatives of the agricultural organisations and representatives of the business community, employer organisations and trade union organisations. It is desirable that they be given the option of being present with the Irish negotiators in Brussels—not necessarily for the full 18 months; I think that would be quite impossible. It is quite inadequate that the Taoiseach should stand up here and say, in effect: “I will brief the Opposition leaders. I will tell them all that is going on.” That is quite inappropriate. If we become involved in EEC negotiations there is a necessity for more widespread dialogue in the nation than is proposed by the Taoiseach.

These are my views on the EEC White Paper. They are my personal views. I do not want the House to be caught up in any false euphoria. I have tried to make a rational, objective and cool analysis of the situation, not on any particular ideological basis. The House should remember that in the 1970s the number of students coming out of the secondary schools will have doubled. By the mid-1970s there will be about 140,000 students coming out of the secondary schools as compared with 73,000 now, as a result of the explosion in Irish Education. We must have an expanding economy to provide them with jobs. In the past eight or nine years about 26,000 students have come out of the vocational schools and we expect that there will be about 46,000 in the future. Employment must be provided for those young persons in this State.

Simultaneously, Irish agriculture must be developed and protected. All the political energy of this House will be needed to ensure that the kind of society we all desire emerges. It is a chastening thought that, notwithstanding the tremendous wealth and the international standing and power of the American economy, an economy which is a vast common market in itself, greater in power and vastly bigger than the EEC, they have not eliminated unemployment and poverty. If we enter the EEC there is no guarantee that we will eliminate unemployment and poverty. In America only a few years ago it was accepted that some nine million families, or 20 per cent of the population, were living below the poverty line. It was estimated that in 1965 that number of families were living on an income of less than 3,000 dollars a year for two or more persons. That was the poverty line drawn by the President's economic advisers.

If, with their power, their technological skills and their own common market, they found it and are finding it extremely difficult to resolve the problems of poverty and unemployment and the problems of geographical and regional imbalance and discrimination, on our entry into the EEC— whether the Irish people decide to go in or not is a matter for them—it is very likely that we will find it difficult also to resolve our problems. It is up to the Opposition and the Labour Party to point out the difficulties and the problems involved. I would hope that our contribution to date has been of value even if it has been lengthy. I want to assure the House that that was quite unintentional on my part and on the part of Deputy Keating. It was not intended as a filibuster. We wanted to put these problems on the records of the House. We wanted to do the job for which we receive £2,500 of the taxpayers' money and we wanted to perform the function for which we were sent here.

Speaker.P: Listening to the contributions from the Labour Party it is very difficult to understand, never mind to assess, the attitude of the Labour Party to entry into the EEC. I was under the impression earlier on that the Labour Party were totally opposed to any idea of entering the Common Market but, listening to Deputy Desmond over a long period last night, it seemed to me from the very many helpful suggestions he put forward in one way or another that there was a change of base, a change of opinion, so far as the Labour Party were concerned. Unfortunately, this morning, again I seemed to detect a hardening of attitude in the speech made by Deputy Desmond. One wonders whether the Labour Party are trying to be on both sides of the fence, trying to guard themselves in case we do get in and, if we do not get in, being able to say they were right. This is an attitude that should not develop in this House or outside it because, once we are in—and it would appear that we will get in—we will need the unified backing of every Member of this House and, indeed, of the people outside it.

Some years ago I had my doubts about the wisdom of going into the Common Market but, when I saw the eager and even the avid approach of our farming community towards getting into this organisation, I changed my opinion. If a body as conservative as our farming community see advantages—and they have been going to Europe to examine and study conditions there for a number of years— in our entry and are prepared to take this chance, the whole nation should be behind them. As a member of a committee of agriculture I attended meetings in Europe over a period of years and I am satisfied that there are very great opportunities for our farmers in the Common Market.

We have advantages that no other farming section in Europe has. We have our magnificent grasslands and limestone soils which are the foundation of our whole livestock industry and which help to produce healthy animals. We produce plenty of grass which gives us the cheapest form of feeding. It is very obvious to anybody going through Europe that none of the farmers there have this advantage. Practically all the cattle in Germany have to be stall fed. The food has to be produced and brought into the houses for the animals. That is certainly not the cheapest way of producing beef and milk.

MainHeading.P: There is and has been for a considerable time a shortfall of 20 per cent in beef supplies in the six Common Market countries. This augurs well for our cattle interests and our cattle production. I am reasonably satisfied from information picked up at many committee meetings I have served on that cattle prices will have to increase by as near as possible to 75 per cent over the present price. This should help to get our farmers off the backs of the ordinary people. This has been said all too often by people other than farmers. I never believed that the farmers have been on the backs of anyone but if they have been it behoves everyone to help them in their effort to get to grips with the Common Market.

The livestock industry can, I believe, be increased fourfold. We have the land, the energy and ability to produce beef and having regard to the fact that there is this colossal market in Europe, it is here that the best interests of agriculture can be served. We have the grasslands and clean, disease-free herds backed up by a very progressive sales system which should be one of the big factors in getting our dead meat into Europe in the cheapest and best possible way. This is of the utmost importance to the farming community and the economy of the country.

I also believe we can maintain if not increase our milk production and dispose of it within the Common Market. In reference to what Deputy Desmond said earlier, I should like to draw his attention to the fact that his figures for surplus butter are not up to date. He said there was a surplus of half a million tons of butter in Europe but recent figures show that this surplus has been reduced practically by half by virtue of a reduction in the cow population of Europe.

Speaker.P: At tremendous cost.

I am not concerned with the cost. I am giving facts. Much of the Deputy's speech was useful but throughout there was a rather authoritative note based on theory. Theory and supposition have been disproved by history. Reference was made to the Mansholt Plan. I can assure Deputy Keating from my experience of Europe, that the Germans, the Belgians and the Dutch are as much opposed to this plan as we should be and are in this country because the Mansholt Plan does not fit in at all with our set-up.
Hear, hear.

It would definitely not work in this country or in Europe either. The bulk of German, Italian and other farmers in the countries concerned have the very smallest holdings. Deputy Desmond gave figures of 76,000 under 30 acres and 56,000 between 30 and 50 acres. I can give better figures than those. In County Kerry 84 per cent of the farms are under £10 valuation and £1 per acre is considered a fair valuation so 84 per cent of Kerry farmers have only ten acres of land each and yet they are the most progressive farmers in the country. They produce one-seventh of the milk of the entire country and nearly one-quarter of our pigs. Those may be startling figures but they are statistically correct. County Kerry farmers have nothing to fear from the Common Market and I can assure Deputy Desmond that the Kerry farmers and those in the rest of the country are confident that they can meet competition from European farmers. We have all the advantages on our side climatically and this is where we can score. No Irish farmer will feel he is less well fitted than a European farmer to stand up to whatever the Common Market brings. Our people can produce and I think we shall find them selling their output to Europe in the condition in which Europe wants it.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Desmond also referred to veal demands in Europe. European veal is different from what we term veal in this country. What they call veal in Europe is baby beef to us; it is the finished animal of 12 to 15 months, the correct type of animal to produce and finish as far as possible in this country. Here we term as veal a calf of anything from three to six weeks old. Let us call it beef because that it what it is. We are better fitted than any country in Europe to turn out profitably an animal of ten cwt at 15 to 17 months. We have room for vast improvement in production so long as our people get the backing and are realistic in their approach. It behoves all of us to encourage them. I am prepared to go to any crossroads in this country, as Deputy Desmond suggested, and I know that those waiting there to hear of the advantages of the Common Market will not need to be told; they know them themselves. Quite a number have been out to see for themselves. Anything we have to say here will not affect their approach. They are a conservative people but once they have made up their minds it is up to us to back them to the limit.

I was rather amazed two years ago to be informed by the German Department of Agriculture that there were 38,000 cows in the heart of Berlin to supply milk to the city. If cows must be reared inside a city, fed and kept there, surely we should have no worry about the position of our farmers. We were shown some of these in Berlin. At least they were there two years ago. I do not know if they are there now. This is the type of competition we shall be up against from Europe and it should not be serious.

I attended the Paris agricultural show with Deputy Clinton and we were amazed to see the various types of cows of all sizes and colours there, not a standardised type. There were very few Charollais there, peculiarly enough, as we thought this type would predominate in France. Apparently, it does not.

The milk problem in Europe is fading out. With the high cost of labour and of milk production the farmer is in a difficult position and it is thought that most European farmers with plenty of other work to do will phase themselves out of milk production. This must be to the advantage of our farmers.

Beef production must also be developed particularly in relation to the suckling calf. Larger farms of 200 and 400 acres should be involved in this. A 200-acre farm should be carrying a minimum of 150 cows of beef type and all too many of them are down to 50 and under. This is where the scope for increased beef production lies. If possible legislation should be brought in to compel people with large tracts of land who are not using it to advantage to lease some of that land to people who would put the right type of stock on it. In milk-producing areas many of our farmers who normally sold the calves at the dropped stage will feed those calves now to a mature stage of 12 to 15 months. Therefore to get the extra production needed an examination of our entire grasslands should be undertaken, if these statistics are not available already, in order to ensure the maximum beef production. Our animals must also be kept free from disease.

On the question of animal diseases, on our entry into Europe we shall have to take every precaution to see that the diseases so common in Europe are not brought into our country. In most European countries, particularly France, foot and mouth disease is endemic. They do not slaughter and the disease is prevalent at all times even although not active. I am sure the Department of Agriculture, who are aware of our record in regard to disease-free animals, will be ever-watchful of that position. At meetings in Europe we have tried to bring about a change in the attitude of France and other countries, but they insist their method suits them. However, we want to ensure it does not endanger our position here.

The encouragement of everyone in this country should go to our farming associations who are so anxious to face up to this challenge. I am satisfied that they will grasp the opportunity which is being afforded to them. We should give them the maximum support and assistance and at no time should we say or do anything that would discourage this approach and this attitude.

Reference has been made to our fishing industry. By and large, we have no fishing industry. Some weeks ago I compared the position in this country with that of other countries in Europe. I said the Faroe Islands with only thousands of a population are producing £10 million worth of fish as against our recent figure of £2.5 million worth of sea-landed, fish. References have been made to protective measures that should be undertaken to ensure that the Europeans do not encroach on our fishing. It would have been much better to refer to the fish which is there and which we are not catching.

There is a 12-month fishing season around our coasts, and if wisdom had prevailed down the years this industry would be a very strong arm of our economy. Our fish landings should be on a par with those of Norway who, having a population somewhat similar to ours, have £100 million worth of fish landings, and employment on land and on sea should be available to about 100,000 of our people. Let us hope that even at this late stage a vigorous attempt will be made to develop this very lucrative industry. There is a market of £186 million within the six EEC countries. That is the amount of fish they must import, and we should be able to obtain a little of that for ourselves if sufficient effort is made. It is unfortunate that fisheries were never made a separate ministry with sufficient money to develop them. They have always been attached to agriculture which is so onerous and complicated that fisheries were left on the outside without the help and initiative necessary to develop them to the maximum.

It is starting that Norway, with only four months of a fishing season, are capable of having an industry worth £100 million, while this country with a 12 months season can produce only £2.5 million worth of sea fish. Let us hope this industry, which could be the saving of the west, will now be developed.

In fishing, as well as in industry, education is going to play a very big part. Agricultural advisory services are absolutely essential in order to get farmers interested in the most modern methods. Such services have helped to a very large measure in my county. We were the first to get the maximum advisory services which were available and that step is beginning to pay off in a big way now. Great credit is due to the men who were sent out ten years ago to get the message across to farmers that the development of grass, the maximum use of fertilisers and individual attention to animal care to prevent disease were essential. As I said, this has paid off and the results are to be seen in the productive effort made in my county.

I have often studied and read about the position of various committees of agriculture in other counties and I am amazed and indeed alarmed at the very small number of advisers which they have. Advisory services are essential and can be very helpful. During the election campaign in Westmeath I was canvassing in certain areas in that county and I was amazed to see the amount of land which had no grass of any kind on it. If the advisory services were available there the people would have a different approach to their agricultural problems. There were two cases which I noticed particularly. One was the case of a very big and up-to-date farmers who had good green fields with a good mat of grass over many acres. At the other end was a smallholder with about 15 acres who had a very good mat of grass but the fields all around him were as bare as the roadway and just as white. This indicates what could be done. These two farmers were using plenty of fertilisers on the land. Advisory services should be extended to the utmost, particularly in good grassland areas, to get across to the farmers the message that they should develop their grasslands to the maximum and thus be able to produce the maximum quantity of beef which can be sold so easily throughout the Common Market.

Deputy Keating referred to the danger to our industrial arm and to the position generally of our industries. I should like to point out that practically all the industries in Kerry, which are mainly German or Swedish firms, are exporting their products to Europe and into the Common Market. To do this they have to pay between 14 and 17 per cent entry duty but still they are in full production. They are developing each year and adding extensions to their factories. This, therefore, is the answer to Deputy Keating's suggestion that our industries will be in danger. Why should our industrialists be afraid of a clash with the Common Market with all the organisation they have both in the way of trade unions and executive ability? Why should they be afraid of entering the Common Market when our farmers are eager to come to grips with it and to get in? Our industrialists are capable and competent. Those who are not yet organised should get organised now while they still have time and then they should have nothing to fear.

We pride ourselves on our ability, our energy and our strength of purpose and we have measured up to the very best. Therefore it is not understandable why there should be a suggestion that our industrialists fear going into the Common Market. It is obvious that we cannot compete against the very big concerns in Europe, but then we will not be competing with them anyway. We are not producing the type of goods or materials they are producing. Our industries are based on smaller outputs of materials and goods which require individual attention and which could not be mass-produced by very big concerns. There is, therefore, plenty of opportunity in Europe for our industries.

Deputy Keating also said he was satisfied that trade unionism here had nothing to learn from Europe. I could not agree with that. Our trade unions do need to be educated. In Europe the trade unions get on well with management and they arrange a working plan for five years which enables the industrialist to book orders. They have an agreed wage structure, at whatever increasing levels are required based on output and this seems to work quite well. They do not have strikes as such. This is one sphere in which the trade unions here can learn and gain. One thing about which the trade unions must be aware is that in many places, particularly in Dublin, trade union members serving behind counters are quite prepared to present customers with foreign made materials and goods as against our own materials and goods. I drew attention to this about seven or eight years ago in regard to a particular firm and I was amazed to hear recently that a lady had to walk out from the same place because she wanted to purchase an Irish knitted garment and the person attending her tried to convince her that a Scottish article or something else he had was far more suitable. All too often in hotels and bars when you ask for a whiskey you will be asked “Scotch or Irish?” They do not even say “Irish to Scotch?” Reference should not be made at all to Scotch whiskey and when you ask for whiskey you should be given Irish whiskey. This is where the trade unions could help.

Speaker.P: More than the trade unions could help.

I know, I am aware that staffs may be forced to some extent to do this because many firms here are foreign-based and they purchase in large quantities materials from outside. Trade unionists could control this to seme extent. They should use every method in their power in an effort to keep their fellow-Irishmen in work. They should ensure that the Irish manufactured article is always shown to the customer. We all know that the home-manufactured product is as good as the foreign-made article, although it may not be presented as attractively. I cannot agree with the statement made by Deputy Desmond that trade unions here have nothing to learn from trade union groups in Europe. We can show our sense of patriotism by ensuring that Irish-made goods are given prominence in our shops and stores and if trade unions would bring this point to the notice of their members who serve in those establishments they would do something really effective to help our country. In view of the suggestions that have been made that we may be faced with dumping, we need all the organised ability we can get and trade unions should realise that by informing their members of the desirability of promoting Irish goods they can help us in this direction.

I am convinced that we have a great future once we enter the EEC. I do not suggest that it will be easy because we shall be in competition with people who work harder than we do and who will use every means to further their own interests. However, it will be a challenge and we have the ability and initiative to meet it.
Contrary to common belief, I consider we have an advantage over the rest of Europe in the industrial sphere.

MainHeading.P: Any factories that will be established here can be so designed as to give maximum production with minimum effort. I have been to many cities in Germany and have seen factories which were divided up into different sections, sometimes spread throughout many parts of the cities. It is a well-known fact that because of the land shortage factory-owners on the continent very often have no choice but to locate their businesses on any sites that are available. That situation will not arise in this country and it is possible for an industrialists to design his factory in one complete unit and to have the manufacturing process carried out under the same roof.

In Ireland we are ideally qualified to produce high-class, specialised goods which can find a ready market in many parts of Europe. This is an area that should be explored and I am convinced it would be greatly to our advantage to do this. We were mainly concerned about our prospects in the agricultural sphere but I have no fears in this regard. The prospects for our farming community, which comprises a large part of our population, are good. Hard work will be necessary but the rewards are there and I am convinced our farmers will reap the benefits.

Members of this House should give all the necessary encouragement and support to our people. We should not display a gloomy attitude because fears do not exists among the farming community regarding our entry into the EEC. On the contrary, farmers are eager to enter the Common Market and we should give them all the assistance we can. It is clear that large quantities of beef are required in Europe and this is one area in which we can reap many benefits.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: One cannot but admire the evolution of the EEC. One must recall that this co-operation between countries developed after the second world war-a war that ravaged the countries of Europe and destroyed much of their economies. The progress the Communities have made since 1958 merits our admiration. I quote from a booklet issued by the Information Service of the EEC:

MainHeading.P: It is also one of the fastest growing major economic areas of the world. Between 1958, the year in which the Common Market began, and 1966, its gross product increased in volume by 51 per cent, compared with 45 per cent for the USA and 30 per cent for the UK.
This is an indication of the success of the EEC in the matter of economic and industrial co-operation.

One can be slightly disappointed at the progress achieved in Ireland. In the past 100 years our population has continued to fall. We are not a prosperous nation by western European standards and our per capita income is one of the lowest in Europe. It is as low as Italy and Spain. We were not involved in the second world war. We did not suffer the consequences of that war to any great extent. Yet we have not prospered like Switzerland has. Perhaps our industrial and agricultural policies have been a failure; by that I mean our capacity has not been utilised to the full. This is a sad reflection on the policies pursued over the last 30 and possibly the last 50 years.

I believe we have decided to seek membership of the EEC because Britain has applied for membership. We are tied to the coat tail of Britain in matters of trade policy. This is unfortunate but for historical reasons it is unavoidable. We should have applied for association to the EEC in 1958. I think the Government were neglectful in not doing so. Association would have permitted us to gain access to European markets for our agricultural produce and this would have led to an increase in exports to the EEC. Over that period our balance of trade with the EEC has been very much against us, yet the Government have made no attempt to rectify the imbalance. Our whole foreign policy is open to criticism. Apart from Britain, we have allowed ourselves to import from numerous countries, especially the EEC, far more than we have ever exported to them. We should have been tougher and gone to western Europe and eastern Europe and said, “Unless you import £10 million worth of our goods we shall not import £10 million worth of your goods”.

Unless our negotiators obtain a very hard bargain on a number of vital issues I feel it will be a mistake to go into Europe. No one can say what the outcome of the negotiations will be, but after the negotiations we shall have a referendum either on the constitutional changes required or on the straightforward issue of entry or no entry. Our negotiating team should be as strong as we can make it. It should not merely be a team of civil servants: successful businessmen, industrialists and academics should be invited to help our negotiating team in Brussels.

The implications of membership of the EEC must be carefully considered because almost every aspect of our way of life will be affected if we join. Our agricultural community will be most affected. I am very enthusiastic about agriculture provided we get free access for our products on all European markets at all times of the year. An enlarged Community of approximately 250 million people has much to offer our agricultural industry. I think this in the mainstay of our argument for going in. It was indicated in the White Paper on Agriculture and Fisheries in the EEC that 65 per cent of our agricultural produce can command higher levels of prices in the EEC. It must be remembered that the EEC is a protected agricultural market; it will be protected from outside imports. Imports from countries such as the Argentine, Australia, New Zealand and the eastern European countries will not be permitted. Our advantage lies in our gaining free access to those markets without those countries being allowed to gain access to our markets. America is a protected market for its citizens and the EEC, as at presently constituted, is a very protected market. The benefit for us lies in the continued protection of the EEC, especially in matters of agriculture.

This must be borne in mind by our negotiators. Our negotiators must not only worry about our position and our direct application but they must also worry about our competitors. We will allow European countries to market their goods in our country and we will allow their workers to come here. This must be on a reciprocal basis. We must not be denied the fruits of our agricultural competitiveness by seeing other outside countries allowed into this market. I hope our negotiators will not overlook this vital issue.

In general, State aids to agriculture will cease. The structural State aids which help to alter the structure and increase productivity by current subsidies will not go. We have come to associate subsidies with the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Area Agreement and these subsidies will go. Support prices for pigs will go. We will be dealing with a different market. I hope we will leave the cheap food market and go into a dear food market. This would have an effect on prices. I will deal with this point later.

I should like to indicate that the common guide price for cattle in the Community is 287s 10d per live cwt. This is 60 per cent above the level of Irish cattle prices for fat cattle in 1969. This is good. The European Community offers Ireland an excellent market for our cattle but it offers it only for quality beef and not for fat beef. Europeans will not take fat meat. Our breeding policy must be realised. I am enthusiastic about the Charollais breed. I do not propose to discuss the breeding of cattle now. We must be careful about the breeding policy in relation to beef. On page 36 of the White Paper it says:

The long term outlook for beef in an enlarged Community, on the basis of OECD forecasts for the period up to 1985, is one of consumption exceeding production leaving a sizeable deficit to be met by imports.
That is a good omen for the future of our beef cattle.

We have an excellent market awaiting us for our sheep and lambs. I must condemn the Fianna Fáil Government over the last few years for allowing the sheep population to drop by over one million. It is unfortunate that this happened because sheep and lambs are very saleable animals. There is a solid, permanent market for these animals, especially in France and possibly in Germany. Our Government have failed the farmers by allowing the sheep population to drop so drastically.
The problem of milk is a complex one and is not easily explained. On pages 37 and 38 of the White Paper it says:
...it is clear that membership of an enlarged Community would result in a substantial increase in the price of milk to Irish producers.

The price would be approximately 3s 9d as against 2s 7d per gallon at present. This is good. There is substantial over-production of milk and butter in Europe. Whatever happens and whether the Mansholt Plan is accepted and adopted or goes by the board is a matter for the future. I feel we are protected from price falls through the European Agricultural Guidance and Guarantee Fund. This is a stabilisation fund by means of various types of export subsidies, domestic subsidies, an import system and by threshold price systems. This is the fund which regulates the market for our agricultural produce in Europe. In the long term I feel we would be successful in the milk and butter industry in Europe. I say this without 100 per cent conviction. I feel that the European governments will not allow large drops in prices over the years. They will be forced to maintain the price of milk and better. Whatever surpluses arise will have to be exported with the help of subsidies from this fund.
It is interesting to note that the method of financing this fund will lead to a substantial saving to the Exchequer. On page 120 of Irish Agriculture and Fisheries in the EEC it says:
As from 1st January, 1975, the Communities' resources, out of which the Fund will be financed, will be made up as follows:
(a) the receipts from import levies and special sugar production levy;
(b) the receipts from customs duties;
(c) the revenue derived from a rate not exceeding one percentage point of the standard value added tax.

This is a system new to Ireland. Further on in this chapter it says that there will be a saving to the Irish Exchequer of £36 million and that it will cost us in contributions £19 million. There will be a net saving of £17 million to the Exchequer. This is a reflection of the changing-over to the higher-priced European food system as compared with the British low-priced food system. The guidance section of the fund is essentially committed to structural improvements in agriculture.

We have structural agricultural problems, such as problems of fertilisation, problems of land drainage and so on. It is my belief that we can benefit from this fund under EEC membership, but our negotiating team must be very clear as to what it entails.

The Mansholt Plan is a plan for the improvement, in Mansholt's opinion, of agriculture. It is a plan for the elimination of large surpluses and for the rationalisation of farming. It is worth studying and has been considered within the Community but, as yet, it has not been adopted. In so far as milk production in Ireland is concerned, its adoption would be dangerous. It would be dangerous in so far as the agricultural structure here would have to be altered and, if altered, could lead to substantial emigration; and this is something which I and, I am sure, everybody else in this House, would not wish for.

According to the previous speaker, Deputy O'Connor, our fishing industry is non-existent. I come from Waterford and in my constituency there has been built a new harbour at Dunmore East for the specific purpose of having a port for the landing of fish in the south east of Ireland. If one goes out there during the fishing season one will see Dutch, English and other trawlers of various nationalities using the port but one will notice that these trawlers are much larger than the Irish trawlers. This is wrong. It is disappointing that we do not have competitive trawlers that can go out into the deep sea and fish successfully with all modern radar equipment and navigational aids. Development has been lacking in the fishing industry in Ireland. This industry, if properly equipped and adequately financed, could be much greater than it is. The Government have failed to provide sufficient State aid in the form of grants. They have failed to guarantee proper marketing facilities. In other words, they have failed to make use of sea fishing, which is one of the great natural resources of our country.

I do not believe that there is a great future for pig meat within the Community. There is a limited market for pigs and lightweight pork but this market could be developed. As was pointed out in the White Papers, feeding costs have increased and will increase further on our accession to the EEC. Many of our small farmers have always reared pigs. This has been a good sideline for them but it could be a profitable mainline for small farmers in Ireland. The Government have allowed feeding costs to increase out of proportion to selling costs. The recent increase in the price of pigs, as announced in the Budget, has not been fully implemented and the claim submitted to the Minister by the Bacon Curers Society has led to nothing. The increased prices allowed by the Minister were miserable when compared with the increase that was asked for justifiably and which was based on feeding costs and increased labour costs. Indeed, it was based on a survey of the marketing conditions that will prevail during the coming year.

It is only by increasing the factory prices that our farmers can benefit from so-called guaranteed prices. The farming community are not happy with the profitability of the bacon industry. This could be a much more prosperous industry. Our factories are working to only 50 per cent capacity. There is a lack of markets and a lack of belief by the Government in the future of the bacon industry. This is a reflection on the Government and it is bad for the farmers.

In the matters of animal health, the Irish people can hold their heads high but we must be very careful in this respect in going into Europe because foot-and-mouth disease is widespread on the Continent. Infected animals are not killed but are merely injected and immunised if possible. The disease is endemic throughout the Continent. We must not allow live animals to be imported from there to this country because there would be a very real danger of importing foot-and-mouth disease. This would have dire consequences on our exports to America because we would not then be allowed export beef or meat of any description to the States.

Our food processing factories must be modernised to comply with modern hygiene standards. Again, there is not enough State aid in this field. It is not enough to give a grant of 25 per cent for a modern factory. In this sphere, too, there is a lack of interest on the part of the Government. Of course, they have other matters on their minds at this time.

On balance, I will leave the question of agriculture on an optimistic note. I am optimistic about the future for our agricultural community but we must be very careful in our negotiations to get free access for our products and prevent outside countries from getting access. England would be a great danger here because she would be seeking access for Commonwealth countries. We must tread very carefully here. We must be hard bargainers. We can become the kitchen of Europe if we manage our negotiations properly but, on the other hand, we could throw away the advantages we have by not insisting on our rights.

Frankly, the problems facing industry worry me. The scale of industrial production, except in a few industries, is not on a sufficiently large scale to survive in Europe. The numerous CIO reports have indicated this with regard to certain industries. The White Paper paints a relatively rosy picture but it does not deal in depth with the problems facing industry. I must criticise the White Paper for not giving adequate information in relation to the effects of our entry on industry. I feel we will be faced with unemployment in a good number of industries. We must in our negotiations again insist rigidly on an anti-dumping clause. This is very important because whatever chance we have in industry with fair competitive circumstances we have no chance whatever if dumping is allowed.

We can, on the basis of a developing nation, on the basis of regionalisation, continue to offer grants to new industries. This is important but it is, again, a matter for our negotiating team. The White Paper would lead one to believe it is possible to continue with the grants. It is essential for us who are relatively undeveloped in the matter of industry to be allowed to continue offering those grants and also tax free profits for a number of years to foreign companies and to Irish companies. In this respect we must ensure that those who become redundant will have every chance of being re-employed in other industries. We must ensure that labour is retrained where necessary, that there is free movement throughout the country.

Let me discuss for a moment the free movement of labour within the Community. In the EEC workers will be free to go from one country to another at their discretion. They can come to Ireland and they must be treated as if they were in their own homeland. They must have access to the same working conditions, the same social security benefits and the same unemployment benefits as appertain to Irish citizens. This could lead to substantial immigration from southern Italy or Spain even. This could magnify the problems of unemployment. There will be unemployment according to the CIO Report and nobody should doubt that.

We are taking a chance in relation to Irish industry. I hope we do not revert to the Act of Union. I hope the consequences of the Act of Union do not again manifest themselves in Ireland where in the early 19th century Irish industry was wiped out for 30 to 40 years because of free trade. I think, on balance, this will not happen. We must at the negotiating table ensure that the employment of Irish people is protected as much as possible against unfair competition.

I feel that the right of establishment in Ireland is good. It will lead to more competition. I welcome it in such spheres as banking, and insurance. Up to very recently in banking circles you had a tight semi-monopolistic ring. Competition does not exist in banking in Ireland. This is very bad and is detrimental to the national interest.

You also have this ring in insurance where premiums are fixed and competition is lacking. The free movement of capital will lead to much more competition which I believe will be good for Ireland. Monopoly leads to inefficiency and also to political patronage. Competition will do away with that to a certain extent.

We have much to improve on in the matter of industrial relations in Ireland. The rate of industrial disputes here is the highest in Europe. Last week I asked the Minister for Labour to introduce a 60 day cooling off period but this was rejected. This is a mistake. We must have better industrial relations. If this is to come about it depends largely on the Government's policy in the matter of controlling prices. Little headway has been made in relation to a prices and incomes policy. Year after year, for the past ten years, we have seen major industrial disputes disrupt the economy. That is wrong. It is something which is avoidable if the Government act sensibly in relation to price increases, budgetary policy and taxation policy in general. Increased taxation and increased prices have led to wage claims. It is hard to know who is to blame or which comes first—the chicken or the egg. We will have to cry “stop” at some point because Europe is a very competitive community. If we stick our heads in the sand and if industrial dispute follows industrial dispute we will not succeed in Europe.

We must have a more realistic prices and incomes policy and a more realistic approach to strikes, especially unofficial strikes. We must have a realistic approach to demarcation, to the question of who does what. Trade unions must be flexible in their approach to industrial problems and employers must also be flexible. Many employers are out of date in their approach to industrial relations and in relation to the improvement and the development of industry. This is holding industry back. Something will have to be done. Nothing has been done in the last ten years to rectify the position. This is most unfortunate.

The social policies of the EEC are quite specific. Every effort will be made to eliminate poverty. Poverty will never be eliminated. Here in Ireland, despite what the Government say, there are many people, in receipt of incomes below the breadline level, living in deplorable hovels. This problem has not been successfully tackled. There will have to be a crash programme to do away with slums, provide better housing and have a more human social security policy. Social policy must be geared to providing a minimum income. That is being attempted in Europe. We will welcome this, but we have not come to grips with the problem at all. It has been left to voluntary bodies, who are doing a very good job, but they have not really got the goodwill of the Government. They are left to work on a voluntary basis. We have not come to grips with the social problem here. Perhaps we will be forced to do so upon our accession to the Community.

The position of sterling will have to be reviewed because we will have to re-align our monetary policy towards Europe. We should have greater control over the inflow and outflow of capital. All foreign moneys moving into and out of the country should go to the Central Bank rather than the commercial banks. We should have an exchange control policy, not necessarily designed to restrain the movement of capital but to keep capital under control so that we will know exactly what is happening from the point of view of the balance of payments and the use to which the capital is being put.

In the EEC we will be subject to the policies and rules of the Community. There is a short-term economic policy committee and a committee of governors of central banks. There are medium term economic policy programmes. There is a memorandum on plans for short-term monetary support to member states. We will have to seek permission to devalue and to take steps to rectify balance of payments deficits. We will have to discipline ourselves in matters of monetary and economic policy to a greater extent than heretofore. Perhaps this will be a good thing.

The balance of payments deficit last years was of major proportions and there is every likelihood that there will be a similar deficit in the current year. Fears in the tourist industry have been confirmed. This is very serious. We cannot continue in this way. The Government have done nothing to control prices. This is serious. This is the real crisis in our community, not the political crisis. The political crisis is important only to the Fianna Fáil Party. The real crisis facing the country is the crisis on the economic front, a crisis of rising prices, a crisis which affects the lives of all our people. There has been an unprecedented rise in prices in the past year and all the indications are that prices will go on rising. The Government do not seem to care a damn about increased prices. They have played politics with the economy for far too long. The balance of payments deficit is of serious proportions. The Government appear to be turning a blind eye to it. In my opinion, because the Government have neglected economic policy, they have thrown away an advantage in foreign markets. Five years ago we had a tremendous labour cost advantage. I would have been very enthusiastic five years ago about industry and its future in the Common Market. Now, because of Fianna Fáil economic policies—or the lack of them—I cannot so hope. This Fianna Fáil Government have thrown away our advantage and I must condemn them in this respect perhaps more so than in any other respect. They have completely and utterly lost control of the economy. In the last Budget, £10 million had to be set aside for wage increases alone. This indicates the magnitude of our inflation problem. Furthermore, this Government are discredited by the events of the past few months. I may not expand on this.

Our approach to education will have to be re-examined. Greater emphasis must be placed on the teaching of foreign languages. We must adopt the most modern techniques for this purpose. Perhaps we shall be forced to modernise our approach to examinations. I feel myself that the leaving certificate, as it at present exists, is outmoded. I consider that the intermediate certificate should be designed for the 17-year-old age level and that this would be the examination necessary for people leaving school. It would also be the examination which would qualify adolescents to enter trades and professions. For those who want to go on to higher education, the matriculation could be taken a year after. Our approach to the whole problem of education in this country needs to be re-examined in the light of modern developments and modern requirements.

All in all, there will be many developments if we ever enter the EEC. The negotiations have just commenced. They may not even conclude successfully, in which events I hope the Government will take steps to form an association with the EEC. If Britain does not succeed in getting a strong and successful agreement she will not go in and therefore, I take it, from remarks passed here and there, we shall not go in either. In that event we should certainly look for association. If we do go in I think we can still be a sovereign independent State. A red herring has been dragged into the discussion by some members of the Labour Party: we can still be a sovereign independent State just as much as England will remain sovereign and independent.

Every aspect of our national life will be affected. We can remain insular, possibly, and be successful in so far as we might survive at a relatively prosperous level but, in remaining insular, our population will continue to decline. By accepting the challenge of Europe I think we could have an increasing population and a repopulation of the western areas. Therein lie my hopes.
