I cannot say for certain, any more than the Cabinet, Fianna Fáil or anyone else in this House can say for certain, that we shall enter a utopian state: we shall not. There will be challenges. There will be failures. There will be disappointments in some fields and successes in others. It is a great challenge to the Irish nation which, on balance, I agree to accept on the assumption that our negotiating team will successfully conclude a very hard economic bargain for the Irish nation. It will be a long, hard road, if we do go in. I feel that, if we get a proper agreement with the EEC, the Irish nation will benefit.

Speaker.P: I agree with Deputy E. Collins that this is a challenge. This should be the thinking behind the matter. This is the challenge of the 1970s. We have been speaking about it for nine years and talking about our possible entry into the EEC. It looks now as if we are close to the moment of truth when we shall know our fate about admittance to the Community. To me, it will be a great disaster if we are not to join in this Community. We are Irish but we are also Europeans. It may be a cliché to say that, centuries ago, our missionaries helped to spread the light throughout Europe: they saw and accepted the challenge of their time. I do not think we should prove less worthy than those men and women of other times in accepting the challenge put before us this year or next year.

It has been said that we will sacrifice some of our freedom and sovereignty if we go in. This I doubt very much indeed. At the same time, I want to be quite realistic and to state that we are not going on any joy-ride into Europe. It will be tough going from the word “Go”. Our negotiators will have to drive the hardest possible bargain. I have the utmost confidence in our negotiating team to do just that. It will be hard going indeed for our industrialists and for our farmers but this will show the stuff we are made of. As Deputy O'Higgins mentioned, we cannot, all the time, be tied to Britain's apron strings. We shall enter as equal members in a noble concept of a new Europe.

A Labour Party Deputy said the dream of the late Herr Hitler was to have a united Europe and feared, therefore, that this is a kind of Nazi plot. One might as well say that because Hitler liked Wagner's music the many millions of people who like Wagner's music are Nazis. I mention that merely to demonstrate that there has been some unsound argument in this debate. We have the opportunity now to assume full nationhood as an equal member of the EEC

MainHeading.P: Let us be quite frank about it. Were we to stay out voluntarily and go into a period of isolation we would become as irrelevant to Europe as the American isolationists were after the first world war. There were many people in the United States in 1939 who preached this policy of keeping away from Europe. We saw the tragedy which befell Europe in the second world war. Had the Americans not been so shortsighted and had they been there, their voices could have been heard in the Council of Europe and the League of Nations to prevent the holocaust which was the second world war.

Our voice will not be as strong as that of the United States but, at the same time, we will have a voice in Europe. I believe the greatest catastrophe which could befall Europe or the world would be a third European war which, no doubt, would spread into another world conflagration. Robert Schumann, one of the authors of the EEC said Europe was divided and we had war. We should bend our whole energies into going into Europe. If by doing so we could prevent another war, our decision to go in would be justified.

It has been said that the European Economic Community would be one power bloc, Eastern Europe would be another, China another and America another. Deputy Keating reminded me of the Book of the Apocalypse when he painted a frightful picture of the four horsemen riding forth bent on the destruction of mankind. The fact is that, unless we go into Europe with Britain and the other countries and play our part, not in propagating a new power bloc, but in showing that we believe in the brotherhood of man and federation, surely we must face the possibility of another world war with the terrible destruction the world suffered from 1939 to 1945.

That is only one aspect. We will play a noble part in Europe as we did in the League of Nations and as we are doing in the United Nations. The EEC gives us a greater opportunity of playing a real nation's part in the new Europe which is about to be created. It has been said that we are not ready for Europe. That is like saying that one is never ready to get married. We cannot dictate the time of entry. We can only hope that, by showing our willingness to be a partner in a new Community, we will be accepted.

This will create many great problems for us but to stay out would create much greater problems. If we stayed out we could not strive so nobly in Europe to play our part in a better world to come. I know that our industrialists will face this great challenge. Since the industrial revolution other countries have had more than a head start on us in the industrial sphere. I am convinced that Irish workers and Irish management are just as competent as the Belgians or the Dutch or the German. If we really accept this challenge and realise the problems, with a good lead from the Government and with the co-operation of the people, we will not fail in this great undertaking.

As I said, it has been suggested that we are not ready to go into Europe and that we should seek some form of association with the EEC. Five years ago, or less, I thought there might be something in this thinking and that, perhaps, we should seek association. Deputy FitzGerald made a very fine contribution in which he pointed out the fallacy of seeking an easy way out and having a foot half in the camp and half out. That just is not “on” at this time. We must go in there as full members having striven for, and I hope achieved, the best possible conditions. We will not be cut-price members. We will be in there playing our part with the Germans, the Belgians and other people. We will not be regarded as the sick man of Europe.

We will be welcome there. We will be appraised because of our past. We have a great sense of freedom. We will go in there and I hope we will contribute something to the new Europe, because Europe wants freedom not colonialism. The nations will be all working together to create a better way of life for the people of Europe. I hope the European example will be followed by other communities seeking, not imperial domination and not economic domination, but a better world which most men dream about and most men believe in even if they differ about the way to achieve it.

Never before in history have we been given this opportunity. We may think ourselves fortunate that, after 50 years of self-government, the opportunity has arisen now. In the past decade we made tremendous strides in building up our economy, so we stand a very good chance of playing a full part as a member of the EEC. Despite the disadvantages or the temporary handicaps we will face, we would not be worthy of this nation if we were to say we are not going in because this is just a plot by the European economists or, because, as it is said, we will shed some part of our sovereignty should we go in.

The Community offers a new concept of nationalism. Sovereign nations will be giving up something for the common good. Surely it is the highest ideal of man that we should do this. In the new concept of nationalism we will be in the EEC, not as a partner lagging behind Britain, but on equal footing, for the first time in modern history, with Britain, Germany and Belgium. This is the great prospect before us. We will go into the EEC as a nation.

The Community will recognise existing political boundaries but, if we stayed out because we do not recognise the unnatural division of our country, that would not bring about unity any quicker. In fact, the opposite would be the case. When we are in Europe that will make the Border between the 26 Countries and the Six Counties even more silly than it is at the moment. The physical border will have disappeared and many people will wonder why Partition should be continued when it is irrelevant.

If we can remove the physical division between us, we can concentrate on removing from the hearts of our people in the north any doubts they have as to what would happen to them in a united Ireland. We would show them our sacrifices in going into Europe in the cause of European unity and therefore we could say to them that when we are prepared to make these sacrifices in order to create a better Europe, surely they, who differ from us in regard to the concept of one Ireland, will make some sacrifice so that their children will have a better future and a better life than our generation had.

The name “unionist” would suggest union. Up to this to be a unionist in the Six Counties meant that he wanted to be in union with Britain, but the time has now come when we should suggest a wider concept of Unionism, unity in Europe, where they can play their part as part of our ancient nation. The people of the north with their skills in shipbuilding and other industrial undertakings could come in and play their part as free men in this great new Community. Even if they approach this from the point of view of self interest they must realise that in this new Community there is a great future for the industrial undertakings in which they have become so expert. This may dawn on many people who are at present opposed to Irish unity. They may well see that there is an opening for them in the new Community and at the same time they can play their part as Irishmen. They will not be one bit less Irishmen and neither will we by accepting the new Europe. We should prove ourselves cowardly if we tried to become an insular group on the edge of Europe. Civilisation would pass us by and the great developments would take place without us.

People have said that by entering Europe we would lose our identity and our language. I do not accept this. I have always noticed that if one goes to Europe on holidays or business how often the people with one refuse to speak English and even those who are not fluent will speak Irish abroad. They then feel the challenge of Europe. They do not become any less European by speaking their own language. They have shown willingness to speak English, French or German, but they also want to impress on the Europeans around them when abroad that they have a language and culture of their own. This is what we want to bring to Europe, the culture of a small nation, a new State perhaps but a very old nation. That is what Irish freedom is all about. Men of past generations did not strive to create an entity here that would refuse to co-operate with Europe. Our whole history has shown how willing we have been at all times to join the Europeans in building a better world. The opportunity is now here and I feel we shall make good use of it.

Again, I emphasise that wishful thinking will not achieve anything and that great effort is required on the part of everybody in Ireland to improve the economy, safeguard our language and cultural inheritance. When the enlarged Community is set up and operating we shall get to know the European mind better than we do now. We shall see that far from being a Nazi plot, as suggested by members of the Labour Party, this is a noble concept of a new unity in Europe. It has also been said by members of the Labour Party that it is just the tycoon idea of a cheque book conquest, but if we think of men like Haferkamp of Germany and Mansholt of Holland we cannot call them capitalists in the sense that the Labour Party speakers mentioned capitalism. As far as I know, Haferkamp is a socialist in the European sense and has no outdated Victorian concept of socialism, but his is a socialism that I think every Member of the House shares in that we want to create a better life for our people.

We want life in Europe not to be interrupted every 20 years by war. We do not want to see again millions of refugees on the roads of Europe and we want to play a part in preventing this. We have kindred souls in the associated countries striving to create the EEC. They suffered more than we did in the last war and the lesson of that war will not be forgotten in Europe for many generations. By then we hope mankind will have learned that peace and sanity are necessary even for self preservation. This is the whole basis of this great ideal, to unite Europe into one Community not with one Government but with a delegate of each Government a member of the central body so that each nation will retain its identity.

This is no dream of a Hitler or a Caesar; it is a dream of the European people like Robert Schumann and others. It is a noble concept and I dislike hearing it derided by speakers as a capitalist or Nazi plot. It is no such thing. Like the fat boy in Dickens, it is easy to make the flesh creep with talk of atomic holocausts, massive unemployment and emigration and so on, but let us raise our eyes and see what is in this for us, if we want to be materialistic. Let us examine what is in it for us. On the industrial side I believe our industrialists have made tremendous strides, especially in the past ten years, and that the time is coming—indeed it has already arrived —when the home market is far too small to be a challenge to the industrialists and workers, those who create wealth. Therefore, we are going into a market of 250 million people who will need clothes, footwear, food, housing and so on. If we can play a part in this for the betterment of Europe I believe we shall see our unemployment problems solved, not by having surplus workers emigrate but by the fact that in our own country we can maintain our quota of supplies to the new Europe thereby giving employment at home.

At the same time we must face the fact that from now on there will be emigration of a different type. Whether we go into Europe or not, there will always be some emigration. In the emigration of the future I hope it will be our technicians, so well trained in industry and agriculture, who will go to Europe to help in this great undertaking and that they will be able to show that our products can face competition with the products of any other country.

We must not neglect the ambitions and achievements of the EEC in the help they are giving at the moment to 16 African states. This is not neo-colonialism, as has been stated by my friend on the left. It is a generous attitude to the developing African nations. Here are the advanced countries of Europe who are not just satisfied to create an affluent and well-fed society but who are willing and, indeed, eager to show that Europe, after 2,000 years of history, can come up with something better for the developing African states than mere exploitation.

The African states are not equal partners yet but since the war they have been emerging towards the ideal of playing their full part in a better world. It is to the credit of the European people that so early in the formation of this new community they can take time off to think of how they can help these developing countries. It is very hopeful for the future that Europe, which is so advanced in technology and such a rich continent, is eager to share the products of the area and give financial aid towards the development of those African states.

It is said that if we go into Europe we shall be sacrificed to the vested interests in the Community. There is a colossal fund available in order to help a partner or a member who is having trade balance difficulties. This may be done from motives of self preservation, although I do not accept this, but the Community cannot operate with one weak member who would retard the general progress. Therefore, if a member state meets a balance of payments problem which it cannot overcome immediately, it can receive help from this fund. It is not just a subsidy because people are lazy or indolent but because, in spite of trying hard to meet their difficulties they are unable to do so without aid from this central fund.

It would be much easier at the moment to minimise the advantages of joining the EEC and to say we must go into our shell and keep away from Europe. I do not think the vast majority of the Irish people would accept this passive role in European politics. We would be unworthy of past generations were we to hide ourselves out on the edge of Europe and refuse to take part in the great evolution which is going on there. We would become something like the people of Tibet who for their own reasons became very insular. They had the right to do that and would have continued to do so were it not for the fact that imperialist China could not leave them alone. However, this will not happen with the European Community, because it is not a power drive backed up by guns nor the cheque book conquest of the tycoon. It is a very noble concept and I believe we shall play our part in it.

People have said we would lose our sovereignty and that the men of 1916 would abhor the very thought that after all they and successive generations fought for we shall sacrifice something. I cannot see that. In fact, I believe the men of 1916 like Pearse and Connolly would have been in favour of going into Europe in this great movement to create a community of people not always at war with one another, not always having the clouds of war hanging over them.

Speaking to people in the street or at meetings I hear them say: “Yes, we want to go into Europe. Our place is there, but we are worried about what will happen to our sovereignty. Will we just become a very small member of a great community having no voice there? Will our industries suffer and will our workers be forced to emigrate? Will we not be a nation any more? Will we be breaking faith with the Proclamation of 1916 in which we claimed the unfettered right of the Irish people to the whole of Ireland?”

This is a new concept of nationalism, and nobody wants to perpetuate the Europe where a powerful country like West Germany or France would dominate the affairs of Europe. If we have to make sacrifices, I do not think they will be any greater than the German people or the French people had to make. Three times in the past 100 years the French and German peoples have gone to war against one another. This brought great suffering to both those countries and to other countries in Europe and, indeed, to the whole world eventually. Neither the French nor the Germans would sacrifice one inch of their territory but they are now prepared to come together for the greater good of Europe. They are prepared to sink the old animosities which existed for so long and which broke out in such bitterness in 1939. They see, as most of us here see, that were Europe to continue on the old pattern, another war would be due in 1975. Things are very different now and by 1975 I trust the Community will be well on its way to full operation, and we will not be fearing the effects of another world war but we will be working for peace in Europe.

This lesson will not be lost on the rest of the world. Those who say that we will lose some of our sovereignty should realise that the proof of our sovereignty lies in the fact that we are electing to go in. We are not being dragged in or forced in. At the same time, it will be the people who will decide whether we go into Europe or not. Some 90 per cent or more of the people say that this is the path we must follow. People are realistic and they do not think that if we go into Europe everything will be wonderful. We are not asking for that; we are merely asking that we be given the terms which we think are necessary if we are not just to help ourselves but to become a loyal and full member of the Community.

Over the last decade when the EEC was first mooted the Government took steps to try to bring industry and agriculture up to a standard which would allow us to compete in Europe. We have made some progress in that regard but I am not satisfied that we have made all the progress we could have made. In a very short time we will have to be dedicated to the cause of modernisation in industry and agriculture. There is still time to do this and in the industrial sector, between management and labour, we can do this. The fact, of course, is that we have got to do it; there is no way out.

It may be said that the only table which we topped in Europe was the OECD table dealing with the number of days lost through industrial strife. This is a great problem because we cannot afford the luxury of the industrial strife which has been so rampant in our community for some years past. However, I see a ray of hope in the fact that changes are taking place and while capital and labour have fought many battles recently we see that in Cork today the Trade Union Congress are discussing this very matter. They are suggesting means and methods by which industrial strife will be greatly reduced. We cannot afford industrial strife in the European concept. Other countries in Europe also have their troubles and, indeed, there is one country, which I shall not name, which did not have a government for six months. They just could not agree on a government. At least we can say here that while we may have our disagreements in the industrial sphere we can form a government. I am sure that with a realisation of the problem that faces us we will get down to finding out just what is wrong in our system of industrial, or I should say human relations, why we have so many strikes, why both sides, labour and management, as well as the community generally, suffer because of these strikes.

I do not think I am being unduly optimistic when I say that now when we are about to go into Europe we will show a greater realism in facing up to all the challenges which we must face up to if we are to play any part in Europe. Indeed, if we are going to survive as a nation we must do these things. I know it is easy to get up here and speak about what should be done but I have had experience on the factory floor and in later years on the other side and that is what gives me confidence in regard to what we will do in this sphere before we enter Europe. We have much time to make up but the dawn is coming and we can show Europe that we are coming in not just for what is in it for us—although frankly that is our concern—but also for the part we can play in Europe.

Members of the Labour Party have stressed the frightful things that will happen if we go into Europe. I took the trouble to read some speeches of Labour Party Deputies and while two of them did make good speeches and put up good arguments they both asked: “What happens if we do not go in?” This is the kernel of the matter. If we do not go in what will happen? It will be said that we can find markets elsewhere outside Europe but the British market would be gone and what would we do while we sought new markets? It has been said by critics of our application that the future of industry here, that is for both employers and employees, is very depressing indeed. Recently, I read a statement by the Confederation of Irish Industries which stated that if we went into Europe Irish industrialists would have a better time because English industrialists who at present are making terrific efforts to sell their goods on the Irish market would then switch to Europe with its 250 million people because our market then would be very small compared with the European market.

That statement cannot be taken lightly. I merely mention it to show that the prognostications of disaster in the industrial sphere must be challenged. The Europeans do not want us just because of our blue eyes. Things will be very tough for us but not any tougher than we are in being able to face up to this challenge. We have faced challenges in the past and, indeed, our whole effort since the foundation of the State to build up an industrial arm has taken a high degree of thinking and hard work. We have done reasonably well although not as well as I would have liked, which would have meant that we would have nobody unemployed, but then I do not know of any country that has achieved that position yet. By going into Europe we will be given an opportunity of creating an economy and society that will offer our people a good standard of living in their own country. If they wish to emigrate to Europe they will not go as they formerly did to Britain as “hewers of wood and drawers of water”.

It is essential that we perfect our educational system so that it can compare favourably with that of European countries. In the last three or four years we have made progress in giving greater opportunities for post-primary and university education, but we have still much more to do in this regard. I should like to see the new university at Dublin operate like the Free University of Berlin or some of the other great universities of Europe. Any improvements will cost money and entail much hard work, but I am convinced that the Irish people are capable of overcoming any obstacles, whether in the educational, industrial or agricultural spheres.

Although we have been in existence as a State for only 50 years, we are an old nation; and our application to enter the EEC means that we are going back once again into Europe—admittedly a different Europe from that of 500 years ago. We should have a full realisation of what the new Community holds for us, the benefits we can get from association with it and what we can give in return. We should not go along with the view of those who can only see in the Community a plot by financiers and tycoons in Europe. I am not suggesting that everybody in Europe is a true-blue European patriot but I consider that the European people have recognised that it is a choice between confederation or a continuation of the old pattern of war in the Continent—and a trade war very soon develops into a nuclear war. The people of Europe have learned a lesson from the past and have realised how essential it is to build this great new world. This is a noble dream but it cannot be achieved without effort.

It has been mentioned in the White Paper that we must accept the fact that not all Irish industries will survive the challenge. We must see to it that industries worth safeguarding, those which ensure a decent standard of living for their employees, are preserved. It will be a matter for our negotiators to obtain the best possible conditions of entry for us. We realise that the negotiations will be tough and difficult but our negotiating team know our weaknesses and will do their utmost to protect our interests.

We are not being forced into Europe. However, after nine years of discussion in this House and outside, we cannot be accused of rushing blindly into the Common Market. There is, of course, the possibility that we may not be admitted, which would indeed be a tragedy. In common with most people I realise that it is not a matter of a soft place being found for us in Europe; the rewards are there but hard work will be essential if we wish to attain those rewards.

I am not an economist and I would not dare to speak on the agricultural aspects of the EEC. However, having read the White Paper and some of the speeches of Dr. Mansholt and others, I am convinced that our agriculture has a place in Europe. However, our agricultural industry must gear itself to meet the challenge, which I think it will do in an effective way. It would be wrong for me to suggest to any farmer that Ireland will be a land of milk and honey once we enter the Common Market. Let me repeat Deputy FitzGerald's phrase that “it will be a land of milk and money”——

Speaker.P: They already have the milk there.

Perhaps they have too much milk there at the moment. However, I would not dare to explain the agricultural aspects—that matter I shall leave to the experts on agriculture. There are many places in the world where milk products would be of great value to the people and perhaps some day the Community may do something about this matter.
They have one million tons and they do not know what to do with it.

The EEC have shown concern for the less well-off people of Africa and the developing countries and they may find some way of using the surplus milk to convert it into other products that would be of value to the underdeveloped countries.

The question has been posed that perhaps we might become engulfed in the European Continent and thereby lose our identity. It is wrong to assume that this is true. In the past Ireland survived many attempts to smother her identity and had we acquiesed perhaps our country would have had much more prosperous times. It is not in our character to accept this kind of thing. We shall go into Europe as a nation willing to play its part but we shall not lose our national identity in any way.

MainHeading.P: In recent months, as people have begun to talk about our joining the EEC, they have become very conscious of their nationhood. I addressed a boys' club last year and following my address the boys were allowed to ask questions for half an hour. A young boy questioned me on certain aspects of the EEC. I am not an expert on this subject but the very fact that a boy of 12 or 14 years of age had read something about the EEC and wanted to know more about it is a very healthy sign.

The present generation will ensure that we will not lose our national identity. Neither the Treaty of Rome nor the Treaty of Paris asks any nation to give up its identity and say, “We are not Germans, we are not French, we are not Belgian, but we are Europeans”. The attitude of members of the Community is that we are German, we are Dutch, but we are also Europeans. Members of the community seek to create a new Europe better than any Europe we have ever known.

Robert Schumann was the first person I ever read on the EEC. He set out to create a new community and his words about Europe not being united and therefore at war shows that the French abhor war the same as the rest of us. It is not enough merely to abhor war; steps must be taken to remove the causes of war. A trade war is generally followed by a physical war. By setting up a Community such as the EEC steps have been taken to ensure not that we do not have competition but that we have civilised competition. This may be the answer to the international cartels who exploit peoples in the name of trade, even if it means causing war. I am idealistic enough to believe that the founders of this Community had a noble ideal not just for self-advancement but a noble ideal for a Europe, a Europe like that of the Golden Ages, where we shall have real civilisation. We shall not have a Europe where the stronger nations tread on the weaker ones, first, in a trade war, and then in a physical war. This new Europe will not only be better for the people of Europe but for the rest of the world as well.

I do not accept that the Community will constitute a new power bloc which will be in competition with the power blocs of eastern Europe, China and the United States of America. The EEC is a new concept of a community which may well spread, not as a power bloc but as an example of man having rejected the futility of war and the senselessness of war and uniting instead to work in harmony in a community spirit. This nation can play its part in such a Europe.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan
Speaker.P: Deputies undoubtedly realise that the motion before this House states:
“That Dáil Éireann takes note of the White Paper entitled Membership of the European Communities: Implications for Ireland.”
and that the leader of the Opposition has proposed an amendment which states:
“and urges the Government to ensure that the terms of membership to be negotiated adequately safeguard the interests of the people of Ireland.”

Not only in this Parliament but in every European Parliament millions of words have been spoken on the subject and economists have written tens of thousands of lines about it. No doubt they have spent many hours studying the position. Most Members of this House, and probably most members of other Parliaments, will have read all the material and the statistics compiled by the economists, the advice of statesmen and the various editorial comments in daily and weekly journals. It is quite right that we should consider the economists' reports and the speeches of politicians throughout Europe but we should also ask ourselves what the opinion of the man in the street is and what the opinion of the politician is in relation to this movement.

MainHeading.P: There are two things which I do not like in public life——and I am sure Mr. Harold Wilson will subscribe to my feelings on them—and they are economists' reports and public opinion polls. If politicians would pay less attention to economists' reports and take little notice of public opinion polls, and listen more to the opinions of farmers, workers, business people and those engaged in industry and trade unions they would get informed opinions. If our future is to be based on the reports of economists we are in a bad way. We must not accept the results of opinion polls. There is a duty on all of us to give of our best in Parliament and to contribute as wisely as we can to the debate on this vitally important issue. This is the most important debate we have had concerning the future of this country since the establishment of the State. Deputy Cosgrave has clearly indicated the views of this party in so far as our entry into Europe is concerned. This party were not influenced by the fact that Fianna Fáil are endeavouring to get into the European Community, nor by the fact that the Labour Party take another view. The Fine Gael Party felt it was right to try to get into the European Community. The leader of the party has stated on many occasions that we feel Ireland should seek membership of the EEC. This line of action has been supported by everybody in this House associated with Fine Gael.

Why are Fine Gael taking this line? They are doing so because they realise that the world is becoming a small place but, at the same time, it is becoming a very selfish place, where the big and powerful may prosper at the expense of the small and the weak. Fine Gael realise that we have a part to play as a nation and that we can undoubtedly contribute by word and by deed—and I would like to say by example also. Perhaps the future may hold better things in store for us. There is much we can contribute to Europe. It would be disastrous if we could not take our place as a nation and have our voice heard at conferences and be a member of this Community.

The men who founded this State were men of foresight and ambition. Their ambition was that we, as a nation, might play our part in the moulding of public opinion abroad. They felt we should have a voice abroad and should endeavour to bring about harmony and statesmanship. They felt we could help to contribute so that people of different countries to be associated with us would enjoy high living standards. It has been customary for powerful nations to ignore the voice of smaller nations. We have seen in the past that powerful nations endeavour to squeeze small countries out of existence. We are one of the smallest countries in Europe, and maybe one of the weakest, but we must have the greatest traditions in Europe. Denmark may be a more powerful country although it is only the size of Munster. It can maintain a large population. Many thousands of people in Europe, in Africa and in the southern states of America really thought that Ireland was a part of Britain until it was clearly indicated to them that there were separate applications for membership of the EEC from Britain and from Ireland. Many people found out recently that we are an independent, sovereign State. Why was that? It was because of our geographical situation and our proximity to Britain. Britain, as a bigger country, was able to overshadow us in Europe.

I agree fully with what Deputy Cosgrave said in regard to this matter. I agree that we have a duty to stand on our own feet. If we have been dominated by Britain economically it is time that we examined the situation and shook off that domination. We have now a wonderful opportunity of venturing into Europe as a sovereign and independent State. We can go in, if admitted, like Denmark or Britain. It would be interesting to hear from those who think that we should not apply for membership of the EEC what they would say if we did not apply for membership and if Britain applied to be admitted.
Debate adjourned.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Court Procedure.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice what period normally elapses between the return of a person for trial in Dublin before (a) the Central Criminal Court and (b) the Circuit Court and the actual trial; whether there are any circumstances in which a person may be tried before another person returned at an earlier date for trial; and, if so, what are such circumstances and who has the power of deciding such matters.

In the case of the Central Criminal Court, the normal waiting period between the return for trial or the transfer of the case from the Circuit Court and the actual trial is about eight weeks during which, of course, the person concerned is on bail.
